titlestmt.titleproper: A Finding Aid to the Judith Wilson Papers, 1966-2010, in the Archives of American Art AAA.wilsjudi
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Erin Kinhart

note.p: This finding aid is associated with a MARC collection-level record. 322805

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2015-02-27T10:06-0500

did.abstract: The papers of art historian Judith Wilson measure 11.2 linear feet and date from 1966 to 2010. Wilson's career is documented through correspondence with friends, colleagues, artists, universities, and art organizations; notebooks; files on writing projects, conferences, lectures, symposia and other professional activities; and a small amount of printed material. Also found is research material on artist Bob Thompson, including photographs, printed material, correspondence, notebooks and a documentary video recording. Additionally, the collection includes sound recordings of 71 interviews of artists and art collectors and six video recordings.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Judith Wilson (1952- ) is an art historian in San Francisco, California. Wilson began her career as an editor for Ms. Magazine in 1975. In 1979 she wrote a profile of Alma Thomas for that magazine, after which she began writing regularly about visual art and cultural politics, reviewing exhibitions, writing feature articles, and serving as guest editor for several publications. Her research interests included African-American art and black visual culture. She received her Ph.D. in art history from Yale University with a dissertation on the artist Bob Thompson. Her teaching career included full-time positions in art history at University of Virginia, Yale, and the University of California, Irvine, as well as part-time and visiting professorships at several other schools. In 2006 she retired from the University of California, Irvine after eight years. During her career Wilson served on editorial and advisory boards for art publications and wrote many catalog essays, contributed to anthologies, and presented numerous conference papers, many of which were later published.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Judith Wilson papers, 1966-2010. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The collection was donated in 2012 by Judith Wilson-Pates.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The Judith Wilson papers are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Use of original papers requires an appointment and is limited to the Archives' Washington, D.C. Research Office. Use of archival audiovisual recordings with no duplicate access copy requires advance notice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The papers of art historian Judith Wilson measure 11.2 linear feet and date from 1966 to 2010. Wilson's career is documented through correspondence with friends, colleagues, artists, universities, and art organizations; notebooks; files on writing projects, conferences, lectures, symposia and other professional activities; and a small amount of printed material. Also found is research material on artist Bob Thompson, including photographs, printed material, correspondence, notebooks and a documentary video recording. Additionally, the collection includes sound recordings of 71 interviews of artists and art collectors and six video recordings.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged as 9 series.

list.item: Series 3: Writing Projects, 1972-2010 (1.7 linear feet; Boxes 4-5)
Series 4: Conferences, Lectures, and Symposia, 1978-2009 (2.0 linear feet; Boxes 5-7)
Series 5: Professional Records, 1979-2009 (1.0 linear foot; Boxes 7-9)
Series 6: Research Material on Bob Thompson, 1966-2006 (1.8 linear feet; Boxes 8-10)
Series 7: Printed Material, 1981-2010 (0.5 linear feet; Box 10)

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: The collection was processed to a minimal level and a finding aid prepared by Erin Kinhart in 2014. The collection has been minimally rearranged and retains the existing/original folder titles when possible. All materials have been rehoused in archival folders and boxes for long-term stability, but often staples and other fasteners have not been removed. Materials within folders have not been rearranged.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Found here is Wilson's correspondence with colleagues, scholars, artists, arts organizations, and universities. A small amount of personal correspondence with friends is also included. Of note is extensive correspondence with artists Houston Conwill, Judy Chicago, Ana Mendieta, Howardena Pindell, Adrian Piper, and Raymond Saunders; as well as art historians Kellie Jones, Theresa Leininger-Miller, Lucy Lippard, Eunice Lipton, Kymberly Pinder, Richard Powell, and Moira Roth.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Correspondence is arranged alphabetically. Additional files of student correspondence and letters of recommendations are arranged at the end of the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wilson's notebooks include notes from interviews with artists and collectors, studio visits, exhibitions, conferences, and other activities. They also document project ideas and research sources. Researchers should note that notebooks regarding research on Bob Thompson are included in Series 6.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Notebooks are arranged in rough chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Found here are Judith Wilson's files regarding her writing projects, including magazine and journal articles, book projects, exhibition catalog essays, and guest editorships. Some files contain documentation for writings that were never published. Documents may include project correspondence, draft writings, planning documents and agreements, research material, and publications. Not all files contain drafts or final published versions of the writings. Writing projects of note include articles on Alma Thomas, Henry Ossawa Tanner, and Adrian Piper, as well as catalog essays on Hale Woodruff, Alison Saar, and Sargent Johnson. Interviews conducted for writing projects are included in Series 8: Interviews.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Folders are grouped by type of project and further arranged in rough chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Found here is Wilson's documentation on her participation in conferences, lectures, and symposia. Files may include correspondence, planning and travel documents, panelist biographies, programs and event publications, drafts of Wilson's lectures, and slide lists. Several files also include sound cassette recordings of events, as well as electronic discs (CD and DVD) containing planning documents and draft lectures.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Folders are arranged in rough chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Professional records document Wilson's participation in juries, advisory committees, editorial boards, and exhibitions, as well as a few teaching records and other records of professional meetings. Also found are letters to the editor and reader's reports for various articles, book projects, and manuscripts. Files may include correspondence, notes, meeting minutes and agendas, publications, and draft writings by others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Judith Wilson's research material regarding artist Bob Thompson includes research correspondence, extensive research notebooks, index to the notebook, slide lists, and general research material. The general research files include photographs of artwork by Thompson, catalogs and announcements for exhibitions of his work, press clippings and a few handwritten lists. Additionally there are three electronic discs (floppy, CD, and DVD) containing research files. Wilson conducted most of this research for her dissertation, "Garden of Music: The Search for Creative Community in the Art and Life of Bob Thompson (1937-1966)." A copy of the dissertation is also included here. "Bob Thompson Happening!", a documentary by Dorothy Beskind, is available on one videocassette and duplicate digitial copy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A small amount of printed material includes books, magazines, and other publications containing writings by Wilson or other mentions of her work. Also found are several issues of Black Studies Correspondence and a few exhibition announcements.

did.unittitle: Book, The Feminism and Visual Culture Reader
Book, Mythologizing Always by Patricia Jones
Publications Containing Judith Wilson Mentions and Citations

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Interviews are recorded on 97 sound cassette tapes and four CDs. Included are interviews Wilson conducted with artists, their associates, and collectors for various writing projects. Researchers should note that additional documentation on these writing projects as well as any existing interview notes can be found in Series 2: Notebooks and Series 3: Writing Projects. Also found is one interview of Wilson for StoryCorps.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Interviews for which specific projects have been identified are grouped by project in chronological order. Other interviews are arranged alphabetically by interviewee.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Found here are six DVD video recordings including video art by artists Ulysses Jenkins, Barbara McCullough, and Maren Hassinger. Also found is A Brush with Success, a 30-minute documentary film about artist Ed Clark, directed by Charles Martin.
